Inspired heavily by opens in a new window sscaffold.css. I wanted to make my own stylesheet.
Since sscaffold is inspired by so many other minimalist frameworks:

  • opens in a new windownormalize.css

  • opens in a new windowCSS-Tricks Box Sizing
  • opens in a new windowAndy Bell: A Modern CSS Reset
  • opens in a new windowminireset.css
  • opens in a new windowSkeleton.css

I have had to pick and choose what I want and what I could do without. I don't think I'll be documenting that, as it was not extremely well documented originally where things came from.
My goals for making my own were:

  1. Make the system more modular ðŸš¨BUZZWORDðŸš¨
  2. Build a column system that gave me more control
  3. Add in my own personal preferences
  4. Take advantage of CSS Custom Properties

With these things in mind, I went to work.

Opening links in a new window

Since opening new windows with target="_blank" is not announced, it is important to label those links appropriately.
To make this easier, links written like this: 

<a href="..." target="_blank">
  <span>opens in a new window</span>github
</a>

Renders either with an icon or a popup. Here it is with an icon and an inner label: opens in a new windowgithub

You can also use .announce-inline to announce it visually, as well. opens in a new windowgithub

In an attempt to include each HTML element, here is an address block.
Add .address-block to give it a background and some padding

1630 Revello Drive, Sunnydale, CA


1630 Revello Drive, Sunnydale, CA

The address block comes with some premade classes, .street, .city, .state. These primarily just give flair to the address block.
To set up an address block like the one above, copy this: 

<address>
  <p class="street">/* STREET NAME */</p>
  <h5 class="city">/* CITY NAME */<small class="state">/* STATE */</small></h5>
</address>
